Okay, I'm taking time out of my day to recommend this to as many people as humanly possible. Not because the creators are in dire need of money to escape the hellhole that is Venezuela, but to point out how fantastically crafted this game actually is.  Every single element of this product sets the bar at what it sets out to do which includes, but is not limited to, atmosphere, dialogue, soundtrack, character development, story, and world building. You would personally be doing yourself a disservice passing this gem up and I heavily implore that you do not do so.  10/10 satisfied my cyberpunk boner among other things

The following three things are true:   1. I spent 14 hours on a game that is *mostly* about scrolling text and taking in a story. 2. I found myself really sad when I knew it was almost over, I wanted so much more. 3. I had no idea I spent 14 hours on it until I checked and my jaw dropped.  In other words, VA-11 Hall-A comes as highly recommended from yours truly. If that's good enough, feel free to go in sight-unseen. *Definitely* don't be shy if you see it on sale in future, but it's well worth its asking price already. Read on for my input proper.  First of all, VA-11 Hall-A is the first 'mature' game I've played where 'mature' does not mean 'an almost childishly gleeful embrace of all that is violent or taboo'. I mean it's a story about actual grown-ups dealing with grown-up things. Don't let the anime aesthetic or talk of 'waifus' throw you off; this is a story that won't talk down to you, or make you feel like you have to put something of yourself away in order to be able to enjoy. Don't get me wrong; VA-11 Hall-A *loves* occasionally indulging raunchy humor and it absolutely bulldozes straight through certain sex taboos to a degree almost comparable to Panty & Stocking with Garterbelt. But there's a sincerity to it and the humor doesn't overstay its welcome.   I strongly recommend playing it one day at a time. That is, play one game day per one real day. It feels like over the course of a month, I came to know these characters like they're real people. Real people with real issues and whose blossoming emotional maturity might even rub off a bit on you. I walked away feeling like I became just a bit better of a person.   Finally, VA-11 Hall-A is the first 'cyberpunk' story scene I've seen in a very, *very* long time which doesn't overuse its own setting, or force the story to support the setting instead of vice-versa. If you're hoping for some Deus Ex-ish high tale about how the world changed because of one humble bartender, you're going to be sorely disappointed. Again, see above; it's a somewhat realistic story about real-feeling people.  In this way though, I feel like its expression of common dystopia elements are more sincere as a result. Social inequity isn't treated as some cartoonishly over-the-top thing, nor one that can be simply 'solved' with carefully applied stealth and violence like in... well, a video game. It's a thing that hangs over all of life's proceedings and people have to do their best to navigate around it. Glitch City, while a nasty and dangerous place, is portrayed as a unique, beautiful and potential-filled place as well. This is much closer to how such environments are in real life.  On a closing note VA-11 Hall-A takes bold strokes on several progressive issues, but never, *ever* rams them down your throat with awkwardly placed exposition or tokenism. Some of those issues are very close to my heart, so I felt a lot less alone after playing. Not only did I feel like I was heard, but like my feelings were understood.   Very strongly recommended, even if you're not much into VNs. Gameplay-wise, it's almost like a completely stress-free dialogue-oriented Papers Please.

I'm not a huge VN fan.   Fortunately, VA-11 Hall-A gets away from most of what dislike about VNs.  - Atmosphere is conveyed through the art, not with narration. Text is almost exclusively dialogue, and the exceptions are things like in-setting newpaper articles. - Story is not driven by romance. It contains some, but is more about characters' relationships with one another than the center of the story. - Characters are nearly all adults. Not all of them terribly mature. - Though gameplay mechanics are few, they are well executed. You will not serve the wrong drink because you clicked on the wrong thing, only because you chose to serve the wrong drink. - You pick the music; it does not pick you.  The cyberpunk bar setting is fun, the characters are unique and colorful, and while the central story is a tad weak and suffers from hit-and-miss writing, the overall effect of the dialogue makes for an enjoyable experience. As a relatively fast reader, it took me about 6 hours to run through the game once, seeing the good ending and most of the optional endings. Could probably 100% it inside two more hours, if that was something I cared about.  A side note: Author has some fairly transparent biases, but does a relatively good job at making them secodary to the story. A very pleasant change from the rather sloppy and overt hackjobs one sees in indie and even AAA games all too often.

VA-11 Hall-A (Valhalla) is a mix between a visual novel and an extremely simplified Papers, Please. You play as Jill, the bartender of the bar Valhalla, and your goal is to mix drinks and change lives.  The game tells its story through conversations with the clients you serve. Each character has their own interesting personalities, and equally interesting stories to tell. It doesn't provide any options for what you can say to your clients, but it does frequently allow you to choose a drink for them if they cannot decide on a specific drink. This allows you to get them drunk and - naturally, change the outcome of the conversation. If you so desire, you can even serve them the wrong drink, although this will affect you either sooner or later.  The drink mixing gameplay is fairly basic and can get rather repetetive, but that doesn't matter a huge amount if you're one who appreciates story over actual gameplay (although if you appreciate gameplay over story, why are you even looking at a visual novel?)  I wish not to spoil the story, but I will tell you that there are 6 endings you can get.  I can really recommend this game at full price (hell, the fact that I'm writing a review for it says something). I suggest you scroll up and buy it if visual novels and very enjoyable characters are your jam.  It's time to mix drinks and change lives.  I really, really wish the game had trading cards, though. I'd totally buy my way up to a level 5 badge.  Stella is the best character and that is a fact. (Jill and Dana are also great though)

This is best experienced with as little to no spoilers as possible. You would be doing yourself a disservice otherwise, just like a lot of games really. There’s a demo in the Sukeban Games website, it’s worth checking that out first if you are umming and ahhhing if the game takes your fancy. It gives you a very fair sample of what to expect, you’ll get to play away with the simple drink making mechanics, learn about the world of 207x and meet some of the regulars from the main game.   Now, I’m a massive sucker for Cyberpunk stuff. And this game has got me into a real thrust for more Cyberpunk. Now usually, in these cyberpunk games, it will have you being the big damn hero, saving the world from some mad conspiracy or some nonsense like that. But this? Not so much, if at all. You’re just a regular person in the end of the day, surviving what each day throws at you in this mad-tastic world through the eyes of a regular Bartender. Interesting stuff, and a massive change of pace from what i and others are used to.  This game contains some beautiful sprite work, a large cast of likable characters, all living through the ups and downs of being a part of dystopian future society and a stokin’ soundtrack that is just worth a listen in its own right, so go do that now if you haven’t already. The world building is rather well done to, this whole thing is just labour of love and you can see that from the very moment you press start. And if the developers enjoyed making it, then you’re going to enjoy playing it.  Some serious respect to the guys at Sukeban Games is due here. Pints are most well deserved.   If this just interests you, just ♥♥♥♥in' play it.

I've been intrigued by VA-11 Hall-A since I first saw an article published by Siliconera and it got me curious. I was surprised to see this title just magically popped up on Steam and I got excited. The hype was immediately quenched by a simplistic, though fun mixing interface, combined with the challenge of not only making the drink correctly but also the challenge of remembering key details regarding regulars' 'the usual' and the like.  The characters, dialogue, tone, and general atmosphere shine like the developers not only truly grasped what makes the cyberpunk genre so enjoyable, but also with such a fine understanding of great dialogue and chemistry. Each character has their own wonderful backstory and personality that strikes a sense of curiosity in me. I want to know more about these characters, their lives, their history, and I love to be around them. Even the main character begins to flesh herself out which is remarkable.  I was also ecstatic at every sly reference to other cyberpunk/sci-fi wonders like Armitage and Bubblegum Crisis. It's nice to see other people taking such an interest in a genre that sadly goes rather underappreciated. VA-11 Hall-A does not refrain from addressing not only key social problems that exist within our own timeline, but addresses themes like self-pity, self-discovery, bonding, and even sexuality with some character's preferences being left ambiguous or hinted at. It's never thrown out at you or explained to it, it's part of a conversation and truly feels like a genuine one, at that.  Combine all of this with VA-11 Hall-A's incredibly detailed art that truly allows each character to not only be differentiated, but stand on their own in a unique way. You immediately recognize every character, remembering what you talked about last, and the game even encourages you to keep a keen eye on past conversations. Stella definitely stands out as one of my favorite characters in terms of design.  Major kudos out to the folks at Sukeban Games and thanks also to Ysbyrd for publishing this masterpiece. 10/10.

Va11-Hall-a: Cyberpunk Bartender Action. Yeah. This is a bartender simulator. And boy does it simulate something.  -------------------------------PROS------------------------------------  -Dialogue. Bingo, this is the stuff. Some great story telling and it makes this feel like I'm talking to the kind of people who would really visit a hell-hole like Va11-Hall-a. All dialogue is done between either making drinks for your clientele or taking a smoke break.  -Characters. Also bingo, due to the sheer level of awesome characters. Funny hooker-bot who isn't just proud of her job, she let's everyone know about it. Aggressive lesbian girl and her meek robotic-friend. Chauvinistic journalist who orders nothing but pitchers of beer. Even your boss is awesome.  -Music. Easy one to describe, it's good. Listen, and choose which songs play while you work.  -Story. The main character, Jill, has an interesting story, along with others such as Ingram, Stella, and Sei. I think they all bring an interesting tale into the story.  -Environment. A nice cyberpunk backstory creates a nice feeling of being in a new time that has fully humanized robots and talking vending machines that just love 1980's R&B.  -Difficulty. It's not hard. Which is a good idea seeing as the story relies heavily upon your ability to get people drunk or to get them the drink they need to cheer them up.  -------------------------------CONS------------------------------------  -Endings. I thought the lack of more choices kind of hurt the game. I'd like to see how it could have gone downhill harder. And yeah, I don't count being homeless that bad of an ending considering your boss will probably help your sorry ♥♥♥ out.  -Dosing. I thought the idea of being able to dose clients with extra Karmotrine (alcohol) to get them smashed faster was a great idea, but it feels like it has very limited use here.  ---TLDR--- It's a great little game that ads a fun atmosphere to enjoy. I'd love to see a sequel. DON'T buy this on sale, it is definitely worth the price.

My roommates told me I was making a mistake when I saw this at PAX and proclaimed 'Imma buy this' without much more htought. Yet it didn't take an hour before Valhalla captured their attention and had them in my room watching over my shoulder.   A surprise to the many friends I've told, Valhalla IS a good game, maybe even great; It's topical, but futuristic; Forced, but appropriate; cliche, but novel. Valhalla is balanced, not going to far off in one direction to make your average internet denizen uncomfortable. Backed by great visuals and a superb original soundtrack, Valhalla is heavily driven by its narrative elements, told through bar patrons at the 'hell hole' establishment our protagonist Jill works at. It's up to the player to piece together a story, and serve up drinks to keep patrons talking. There's very little actual 'game' elements to the game, scoring even lower in actions-a-player-will-make than TellTale stories. All discussions are scripted, and mixing drinks is trivial at worst; This is Jill's story, not yours, so why should you get to make any choices on what she's going to say? None of this ultimately detracts from the experience, however: Contrary to what it may seem, a heavily scripted on-rails story game is a surprising breath of fresh air in a Steam market dominated by randomly-generated open-world survival games.   Valhalla is a perfect game to grab your favorite drink, sit down, and casually play. It's not perfect, but I've solidly enjoyed my time with it, and it's well worth the price. Valhalla is difficult to put down, and I can't wait to keep playing. Recommended to most gamers.

It's kinda like a less sphincter-clenching Papers, Please and a less gameplay-oriented Recettear had a baby.  I didn't think I was much for VNs. Truth is, I still don't. This grabbed me somehow though. I ended up caring about the characters, even the more insufferable ones. Everyone seemed to have a bit more going onto them then they first let on, which is good characterization in my book. I mean, I installed it and seven hours later it was two in the morning and I only barely managed to convince myself that getting to sleep might be a good idea. Props for that.  It seems obvious the creator has some firsthand experience with chan culture. You can browse threads in an imageboard between shifts and what I read did a good job of capturing what a smaller-scale imageboard looks like. There's plenty of memes and references sprinkled about the game but it somehow avoids coming across as trying too hard. I have to agree with Dana that that is a really cool shiba.  I guess my only complaint was that it felt like the game ended rather abruptly and there were still loose ends in the plot. I get that being a bartender means hearing a lot of fragments of stories and not necessarily ever knowing how they resolved but it was a letdown to have all these subplots going on only for the game to go 'okay, show's over! roll credits!'. Maybe I'm missing something or I could do something different to get the different endings and then I'd get the answers I want. I guess I'll have to do that now.  So yeah, I recommend it. It was cozy. It made me laugh and made me feel gloomy and I ended up feeling close to all the crazy people in this story. Good work!

Basically Papers, Please + Anime + Cyberpunk Setting + Bartending + Character Focus.  Let me start off by saying that this is a very niche game. If you dislike anime and anime character designs, as well as text-heavy games, this game probably isn't for you. Also, the whole 'Waifu Bartending' thing is a joke and there's no nudity or dating in this game, by the way.   Right. Imagine your average cyberpunk dystopia. Corporations have more power than the government. Police forces struggle to maintain order. A large divide between the rich and the poor. Terrorists. Nanomachines. Augmentations.  Now imagine that instead of playing as the big hero who saves the world, you play as an average bartender in an underground bar in a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ city.  Every day, you meet a bunch of clients. You serve them what they want. You listen to their stories while kick-♥♥♥ synth songs play in the background. Many become regulars, who come day after day and change slowly over time. Some don't.  You get to understand the world from the stories of others, which invites the Papers, Please comparison, and I'd say it's a pretty accurate one.  Pretty much every character is well-written, interesting, sympathetic, engaging, and I really cared for them. The game never takes itself seriously, but knows when to slow down, chin up, and deliver some heartwarming moments. Yes, I am not ashamed to say that one particular scene in the second act made me tear up a bit.  Overall, Valhalla is very much a passion project, and it all feels very genuine. It was developed by two Venezuelan weebs who channeled some of their experiences living in a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ third world country into this game. It's just as long as it needs to be (although it ends quite suddenly) and has multipule endings and interactions, depending on what drinks you serve to whom and when. It's worth your 15 bucks if you're even mildly interested in it.

First of all, if you are interested in the game, go get the Demo on itch.io : Why ? Because the content of the demo isn't in the game, and it refers often to what happened in the demo, which I find quite important. It just suffer from a lack of tutorial, but now go and get it, read this review while it download. There is also a prologue if you buy the game on itch.io, but it's more dispensable than the demo and the devs plan to port it on Steam in the future.  Now the actual review,  I'll probably update it later when I'll do the other endings, which may change some of my points.   1st update : Clear my point about replayability, but haven't finishing the game again yet for other endings.   In the this game you are a bartender of the future, Jill, mixing drinks sometimes ( fairly easy ) and chat with the customers, listening to their life in a cyberpunk dystopia. Each one with their own problems, story, stuff, witnessing the impact of certain actual events in Glitch City on them. Instead of living a main plot, you are more following the daily life of many people in the city. Between each day of work you can read some news and threads to know what's going on in the city and buy some stuff so Jill avoid forgettings drinks order when preparing it the next day.   ( --- You camp jump to the bottom to see a resume Pros / Cons. )   The game has a quite enjoyable pixel art, I personnaly love it, there is also very great ideas in the staging of some stuff ( Streaming-chan's chat for example ), the storytelling is very nice and I enjoyed most of the dialogues, which are often quite funny with nice puns, but know when to get serious. The OST is nice, you choose the playlist of the day from a lot of tracks, it is just missing a shuffle button to avoid choosing yourself but there is many titles fitting very well with the cyperpunk theme, plus they are various, from joyful and party like music to more nostalgic and slow ones.   The gallery of characters is just AWESOME , they rarely fall in the stereotype their looks would give them and are quite lovely, each one with their own life and stories to tell, making them quite alive and unique. I loved Dorothy and her extrovert personality.    Plus I saw some people comparing the game with Paper Please, saying they were alike, I'd say no , they are similar in the way that you have a job to fulfill to be able to pay your bills and afford to live, but you doesn't have any of the stakes of Paper Please, no time restrictions for mixing drinks and you can make one again before serving it if you failed one, and you spend a lot more time talking with people than doing orders. It has no dilemna like Paper Please is featuring : choosing if you should let pass some people despite of their false papers.   Now, the cons of Valhalla, remember what I say about following the daily lives of people more than an actual plot ? I don't know if it's that that bothered me at the end of the game, tough It have some kind of a plot, or just the feeling of having some things unresolved and characters underrepresented. Like you see one of them just once or twice and barely know them though you'd like to know more about them !   This is something which I don't know if other endings fix this, because I haven't done them yet, specially because the game isn't very adapted to replay, even by going to the right save : You have mainly to serve a specific drink to a specific moment to get an ending, no problem there, but if you haven't a save on this day you have to replay somes from an earlier save, dialogue will be the same then you'll just skip most of it,  but you still have to be careful what you skip to don't find yourself in a situation where you don't know what drinks to do, because you must pay your bill at the end and can't afford to lose much money with wrong drinks . I started replaying it, the games features a NG+ mode where you keep the stuff you bought, meaning you don't have to buy them again to keep Jill focused, and don't have to look after money that much. Though, it's laborious to skip all these dialogues.  I saw from other reviews that the game doesn't feature many alternate dialogues then you can't really get a different story by serving different drinks.    Pros :   + Nice graphics, I love this pixel-art.  + Nice ideas of staging ( Streaming-chan's chat ! ) + Nice OST, fitting right with the cyberpunk theme and  + An awesome gallery of characters : I loved most of them, and only few fall in a stereotype, who would expect a brain in a jar to hit on girls ?  + The dialogue are well-writed and often funny, tough able to take a more serious tone sometimes.  + Very nice storytelling. + Dorothy !    Cons :   - Some characters you see only once or twice but would like to know more about them ( Makes me expecting a sequel ). -  Hard to jump on another ending once you finished the game because you have to replay some days with the sames dialogues, and can't simply skip them all because of the risk to miss people precise order.  --> The NG+ mode allow you to skip without bothering about money, but it's still long.  - A bit short ? Took me 12h to finish it one time, I would expect more from a narrative game but this is a very small issue. - Low replayability because of very similar dialogues, I haven't witnessed it myself because I haven't replayed the game, but this stand out in many other reviews. It would be nice in a potential sequel to have more control over that through drinks served.  -  I haven't saw Jamie say ' I never asked for this ' once, but I'll try to give him the wrong drink to be sure, this line absolutely have to be in his script  -> I tried it and he didn't say it. I'm disappointed.  - Wanted to see Rad Shiba do more cool stuff and talk more  In conclusion, I loved the game and can only recommend it, a colorful range of characters coupled with a nice story telling, made me laugh often. I'll update the review after doing other endings to see if some of my cons points still stands. Anyway I'm expecting something like a sequel to see these characters again ( Even if the end don't seem to lend itself to ), a bit longer with different outcome in dialogue based on which drinks you give.    8.333333/10, loved it despite few issues at the end !

I've waited months for this, and I'll be honest. I'll originally got this game for the memes. I found this game from /a/ and /v/ and thought stuff like 'Has Waifu Bartending in it, instant 10/10' and 'The creators live in Venezuela for christ sakes, we gotta get them outta there. Support this game!'  But I played the first 'two days' and I could say I'm actually really enjoying it. The atmosphere of this game is comfy and the characters are pretty interesting. I really like the music and I'm interested in the diaologue, which is unusual since I'm more into games with some action.  The gameplay is also fun- they don't just give you a easy order like a Martin- I MEAN BRANDTINI, DAMMIT! Customers usually don't give you specific requests. They usually requests what TYPE of drink they want and want you to surprise them. Gives a feeling of the gameplay being dynamic.   Don't be mistaken, there's definitely some small room of improvement. I literally just finished one playthrough of the game today and I can safely say this is an 8 hours game per playthrough.  Now the simplest way to explain what this game is, imagine if papers. please is a VN with a lot of story and some gameplay. You can imagine that? No? Well then onto the detailed explanation and review then.  Va-11 Hall-A or Valhalla, is a bartending game, with visual novel style as you can see from the screenshot above, well it could as well be considered a visual novel though. It's about a bartender - in this game you play as a bartender named Jill - mixing and serving drinks in a cyberpunk city which life there is hard and everything is expensive ($1000 dollar for discounted beers, make what you will of that). Besides mixing and serving drinks, you'll manage your income but considering everything is ridicilously expensive, you'll struggle a lot. Now this two are the main focus of the gameplay, since if you're unable to give the right order, your customer could leave you early - might not come back but haven't test this yet so do it at your own peril - and your income get cuts in result you'll have to scrap the bottom of the barrels to pay for your needs. And if you fail, you'll end up in a bad ending route and you.  I did mention that this game have a VN style, but unlike a VN, the branching story is dealt by what kind of drink(s) you serve to your client. If someone ask for some non alcoholic, you could give them alcoholic drink and see what kind of response they give to you, or if some regulars ask for something they're not usually order, you could give them something else, and watch how the events goes. As long as you pay attention, it will help you a lot in deciding what kind of drink YOU might want to give to your client.   As for the branching story, too bad the choices you make doesn't really change how the game ends, and it's kinda a shame since it was nice seeing new events transpire when you give someone a certain drinks and they come back some day later or the next day to tell what happened to them. And to top it off, the game give MGS V vibe, where it felt like when the Jill's plot is ended, it just ends without telling what happen with the other plots. It sucks, and I actually care more about the other plot than Jill's plot. True the endings in the achivement involve other characters, but that ending was more about Jill and that character rather than the character plot. Again, it sucks and just makes you - actually, me - crave for some more.  Another good point in the story is for how the character is handled, I must say I quite enjoy the characters (Betty and Deal anyone?) and how fun they interact to each other, and that's why I'm quite disappointed when the game ends after Jill's plot. Should've ended with the bar's plot but yeah that's just me. Now each character might have their own preferred drinks, and if you able to give them that, new event will happen - just like I mentioned before - and also, if you feel like pulling pranks, getting them drunk is also an option, and it will also trigger a new events. So just try giving them drink as long as it's not something weird and something they order too, or hell just give them what you want and see how they reacts.  Enough about story and events, now about the gameplay. it's a cyberpunk bartender action, what do you expect? An action game? Hell no, it a bartender action game in a cyberpunk setting, which means mixing and serving drinks is the only action you'll get, and I guess hearing your client story too. Don't expect any kind of actiony stuff happens here, best you keep that in mind. Again, I have told that the events can change based on what drinks you give to your clients, but it might be a bit hard to imagine. Now think back to papers, please, how did you change the story? By letting or detaining or rejecting a specific individual from your border, and just like that, sometimes at a specific day, you need to give a specific drink for your regulars, or some clients actually order in cryptic and based on how correct your guess is, the event can continue. Oh and also, based on the achievement, you can make a certain character appears when you give a certain character a certain drink(s). And just like how papers, please lets you handle your income, you could get a bad ending route considering how you handle it. Your income is based on how your service is and how expensive the drinks you served is, there is a flawless service bonus that I read that you need 45 sec to serve the order if you want to get. But honestly, on paper it might sound very fast, but in practice, it's too long. And the mixing and serving boils down to following the recipes, it kinda makes it very simple, but I heard if you fail to buy Jill's needs, the recipe will be altered because she's not focused and you need to read the recipe, again I haven't tested this but it's something I gather from a certain place on the internet.  Wow! Holy ♥♥♥♥! You actually read all of that? That's great! At this point you should've get a much clearer picture of what this game is, tell you what, I'll just make a tl;dr above just to annoy you who read to this point :D Nah not really, you're a great person and actually knows that you need to get as much info as you can before buying something and I congratulate you, you have the intelligence that most people seems lack nowadays.   So all in all, this is a very comfy bartending game with a VN style to tell its story and events with a simple gameplay of following the recipes. The game itself is have a nice art imo and a comfy feeling to it. Welcome to VA-11 Hall-A. A game chock full of dank spicy memes and waifus.  But there's a bit more meat to the subject than just that. Sure, the game has a lot of memes and doesn't hide it's anime and/or weaboo influence, but deep inside the game there is much more than that.  The game fully embraces it's influences, and actually creates a believable world around it's themes. Catgirls, sex robots made to look like 12-13 year old schoolgirls... and yet they're all part of this world and believable and don't feel like fanservice throw ins. The game, in this regard, is actually surprisingly mature. To avoid spoilers let's just say that (nearly) all the characters have development and are fleshed out with actual personalities. And never do they ever feel to be in there for the sake of only humor in regards to the game world itself.  In a way, this is a game much like steins;gate in that it benefits from the player understanding many points of the japanese anime 'culture'. Speech manerisms, references to popular anime (Yoooroo Yuuree) and well, the character designs themselves can be more understood and appreciated if you understand some of the nuances. Then again, I feel like this isn't a game people who aren't into that are likely to buy, which is a shame since despite it's outward apperance, it's a great game. The writing is mature and touches on some fairly heavy subjects.  Even the length is actually surprisingly long, but the game is so relaxing that it never feels like it takes up a lot of your time. It truly is best enjoyed with some snacks and a beer to unwind while playing.  The only real bone to pick with the game would be the price. 15€ is a steep entry price, ESPECIALLY with the game being released two days before the steam sale. Yes, people who pre-ordered such as me recieved the game for 5€ which is an absolute steal, but for people who are interested and aren't willing to spend a fair amount of money, or consider 15€ to not be disposable income levels, the game comes at a very steep price indeed.   It's the only real gripe I have with it. It's not game of the year, or probably even month, but it's an enjoyable experience I recommend to anyone willing to get past the whole 'dank anime memes' image of the game. Or hell, even that alone can give you plenty of laughs thanks to the good writing (even though the script could use another proof-read). Overall, wait for a sale. For 10 of your currency, you will recieve 4 or more enjoyable evenings.

Weeeeeeeell.. I haven't finished it yet, and there is no neutral recommendation, so I'll give it a thumbs up for now. Since I feel so on the fence about it, I hope my review will be objective.  Without spoiling any of the story, you're a bartender in a dystopian future society. You serve drinks and listen to people's stories. You can't change the storyline very much, but that's not a problem because the story is ok.  Pros: -The 8-16bit style art is good for the genre -The story is well fleshed out with several avenues of exploring it -The characters are diverse and sufficiently consistently different -The story is pretty imaginative and interesting -The gameplay is simple for a graphic novel  Cons: -The drink making gets old and eventually seems to be a distraction more than something fun to do -The process of dragging each drink REALLY slows down the story (tip for this below) -The ticking of each letter of the dialog onto the screen is too loud and too slow. Clicking to skip it will inadvertantly and unavoidably cause you to miss a little dialog here and there -There is no way to go back to previous dialog in the event that you accidentally miss something -The story can be a little slow at times  Tips that don't spoil gameplay: -Find that sweet spot where you can position the mouse on the corner or edge of a drink ingredient and get it to automatically drag itself on the the shaker when you click. It will take a little practice, but it will speed up the drink making by a whole lot. Making drinks becomes less of a hassel. -Click once to skip the text ticking, but if you click once, read, then double click, you won't have to bother with any of that text ticking at all. If you're not a robot, you will probably screw up a little and miss a line of dialog here and there. Still, this is prefereable to making the game take hours longer to complete for no reason.  Overall: I like the graphic novel nature of the game, but it isn't really utilized well. There aren't enough settings depicted in the game (as in locations), and the gameplay gets boring after a little while. The story is good enough to keep you coming back, but at the end of the day, I'd prefer an ebook.  Buy it if you're really into this sort of thing, but know that it isn't going to be the best thing ever.

Despite the dual monikers of  Cyberpunk Bartender Action  and  Waifu Bartending  there's not really any action, nor is the game focused on romance.  This game's biggest merit is unmistakeably its narrative, but let me briefly overview the gameplay.  While there is no actual challenge in how you mix the drinks, there is a little bit of challenge given to the player in which drinks you serve. Usually it's just a kind of word puzzle, but there are also a number of scenarios that can be reached by offering somebody what they needed instead of what they ordered. Just don't expect the actual mechanics behind mixing drinks to be fun - it is, after all, emulating a job. You can effectively expect a visual novel.  I stepped into VA-11 Hall-A expecting a slice-of-life story about surviving the daily hardships of living in the cyberpunk future. And that is ever-present, but there's a lot more going on if you'll look for it.  Within the dreary shadow of the corrupt, corporate Glitch City, you'll encounter a diverse, well-written cast of characters, with plenty of woes to drink over. There will be entertaining, memorable people, and there will be unpleasant ones with ugly outlooks. There will be people you don't want to, but have to deal with, and you may come to realize that there's more to them than you thought.  The game succeeds at its upfront goal of building a  comfy  atmosphere, reflecting the mood of the bar. It's an oasis from the harshness of day-to-day struggles of Glitch City in much the same way that the game itself is an escape from the hardships of one's own life.  One of the strengths of the game in my opinion is that it challenges the very audience it appears to cater to. Most of the cast is female and even gay, but the script is flipped on how various characters are treated, without seeming unrealistic. Men and women and robots are all objectified and casually harassed. I don't know whether it goes over most players' heads, but it does a good job of showing how uncomfortable and grating it can be, or alternatively how relatable.  On that topic, the subject matter can be quite sexually explicit and very forward. While I think this is actually a very honest extrapolation of how sexually open we as a society might be fifty years in the future, especially  in a bar , this might make some people uncomfortable, so be warned.  The world is built in details that you can glean from conversations over time. Some details are asked for or explained, some are slipped sneakily in the text, and others are offered in optional daily news feeds or threads on the fictional 'Dangerous Opinions' board, Danger/u/, which echoes the daily fears and concerns of the laypeople.  Despite being so character-centric, some very vital recurring cyberpunk themes are addressed and briefly explored, like the nature of digital immortality, or living alongside sentient robots, or what said robots think about The Three Laws, or what it feels like being a good cop in a world full of bad ones.  There is some dark and heavy subject matter encountered across these stories - after all, they are usually being told by people who've been driven to the bottom of a glass - but the game is not without its share of humor (both good and bad) and moments of levity or tenderness. It pretty much runs the full gamut of human emotions, and it's easy to fall in love with because of that.  Lastly, Jill is surprisingly one of the best-written protagonists I've ever seen in a game. Her personality is very defined and her justifications for player actions are always consistent with her character. It's downright refreshing compared to the norm of silent and/or stoic.   Edit: I've nominated this game for THE “I'M NOT CRYING, THERE'S SOMETHING IN MY EYE” AWARD. I didn't go into this expecting an emotional story - everything I'd heard suggested that it was a humorous, cozy, colourful ride - and yet there is a powerful, personal tragedy nestled at the heart of all else that goes on.

It's a great story with a silly drink mixing mechanic attached. I'm in love with it.   'VA-11 Hall-A: Cyberpunk Bartender Action' is a beautiful game. The art style is fantastic, the dialogue is amazing and the story is phenominal. It's been a long time since I was truly sucked into a game that I could just play for hours without feeling tired or bored.   The game does two things very well: story and character development. Even without dialogue options or character customization VA-11 Hall-A is able to immerse the player in this bartender role. You listen to your clients and they listen back. It's such a wonderful experience watching this huge world unfold from behind a counter.  The gameplay is very simple, yet still manages to feel less like a chore and more like interaction. You mix drinks at the bar, check your phone at home and go shopping every once in a while. You're just living out your daily life in a cruel futuristic world where the only light is the bar.  My final statement is as follows. The game feels human. There's no other way for me to describe it. The friends you make, the people you speak to all feel human. Everyone has problems and everyone has emotions that can affect how you see them as a being. It's your job to make sure that you understand them and are there for them and that is what this game is about. Even with the dogs and the Lillim, we are all human in Glitch City.   I won't forget this game.

10/10 I didn't know much about this game, apart from that it looked really cool. I owned this game a long time before I actually got the gumption to play it. But once I started, I was hooked. Mixing drinks, once you understand the rules, it quite fun and something differernt from a bog standard visual novel. I like the idea of what drinks you mix for people changes how things play out, rather than simply making dialogue decisions. You have to pay attention to what a character wants, even if they don't completely voice it themselves (or if they do). You play a character who isn't simply an avatar for you - she is her own person who you're playing alongside and learning about her is just as interesting as learning about your co-workers and patrons. I love the cyberpunk take on things and learning bits and pieces about the world you're currently inhabiting. This game does things a little differently and I really love that about it. Just go for it - you won't be disappointed.
